sen.j: 片桐 且元（かたぎり かつもと）は、安土桃山時代・江戸時代の大名。
sen.e: Katsumoto KATAGIRI is the daimyo who reigned during the Azuchi-Momoyama and Edo periods.
Katsumoto KATAGIRI was a daimyo (lord) who lived during the Azuchi-Momoyama and Edo periods.

sen.j: 賤ヶ岳の七本槍の一人。
sen.e: He is one of the Shichihonyari of Shizugatake.
He was one of the Shichihonyari (Seven Spears) of Shizugatake.

sen.j: 豊臣秀吉より豊臣姓をゆるされる。
sen.e: He gained a permission to use TOYOTOMI surname by Hideyoshi TOYOTOMI.

sen.j: 父は近江国の戦国大名・浅井氏家臣の片桐直貞、母は不詳。
sen.e: His father is Naosada KATAGIRI, the retainer of the sengoku daimyo (daimyo during the Sengoku period) ASAI Family, but his mother is unknown.
His father was Naosada KATAGIRI, a retainer of the ASAI family, who were daimyo during the Sengoku period, but his mother is unknown.
His father was Naosada KATAGIRI, a retainer of the AZAI Clan, who were daimyo during the Sengoku period, but his mother is unknown.

sen.j: 弟に小泉藩主となった片桐貞隆がいる。
sen.e: His younger brother is Sadataka KATAGIRI who became the head of Koizumi Han.
His younger brother was Sadataka KATAGIRI who became the head of Koizumi Han (fief).

sen.j: 近江国浅井郡須賀谷（滋賀県長浜市須賀谷）の浅井氏配下の小領主・片桐直貞の子として生まれる。
sen.e: He was born as the son of a small feudal lord, Sadataka KATAGIRI, who served under the ASAI Family in Sugatani, Azai-gun (district), Omi no Kuni (Sugatani, Nagahama City, Shiga Prefecture).
He was born in Sugatani, Azai-gun, Omi no Kuni (present day Sugatani, Nagahama City, Shiga Prefecture), the son of a minor feudal lord, Naosada KATAGIRI, who served the ASAI Family.

sen.j: 須賀谷は浅井氏の本拠地・小谷城と山続きであり、同城の支城の一つとして機能するとともに、須賀谷温泉が湧出するために湯治場としても利用されていた。
sen.e: Sugatani was connected by mountains to the ASAI Family's main headquarter of Odani Castle and functioned as its supporting castle and a hot spring since it was where Sugatani hot spring water flowed out.
Sugatani was connected by mountains to the ASAI family stronghold of Odani Castle and served both as a supporting castle and a resort, due to the Sugatani hot springs.

sen.j: 元亀元年（1570年）から天正元年（1573年）9月1日 (旧暦)にかけての織田信長による浅井長政への攻撃に際しては小谷城の落城まで一貫して浅井方として戦った。
sen.e: He fought on the side of Nagamasa ASAI until the fall of Odani Castle by Nobunaga Oda's attacks from 1570 to September 1, 1573.

sen.e: The letter of appreciation from Nagamasa ASAI to Naosada KATAGIRI on August 29, the day before the castle fell, is present even to the current day.

sen.j: 且元が家督を継いだ時期は定かではない。

sen.j: 天正7年（1579年）ごろ、同じ近江生まれの石田三成らと共に長浜城 (近江国)時代の羽柴秀吉（豊臣秀吉）の家臣として仕えたといわれている。
sen.e: It is said that he served as a vassal under Hideyoshi HASHIBA (TOYOTOMI Hideyoshi) during the Nagahama Castle (Omi no Kuni) period along side Mitsunari ISHIDA born in same Omi.

sen.j: 天正11年（1583年）5月、信長死後に対立した織田家の柴田勝家との賤ヶ岳の戦い（近江国伊香郡）で福島正則や加藤清正らと共に活躍し、「賤ヶ岳七本槍」の一人に数えられた。
sen.e: He played an active role with Masanori FUKUSHIMA and Kiyomasa KATO to be counted as one of the 'Shichihonyari of Shizugatake' during the Battle of Shizugatake (Ika-gun (district), Omi no Kuni) against the opposing Katsuie SHIBATA in May 1583 after Nobunaga's death.

sen.e: Afterwards, he was active not on front lines as a military general but served mainly as a supporting bugyo, and he worked as the road maintaining road bugyo, supplied military ship during Kyushu Conquest, attended requisition of Odawara Castle during the Battle of Odawara, and investigated the Asari Incident as Oshushioki.

sen.e: He became the lord of Ibraki Castle in Settsu no Kuni (Settsu Province) in 1595 and became the shirodume (samurai that served a castle) when assigned with the Osaka Castle guard duty in 1598.

sen.e: He supported Hideyori after Hideyoshi's death and was given 28,000 koku Tatsuta Han in Yamato no Kuni after the Battle of Sekigahara in September 1600 by Godairo Ieyasu TOKUGAWA.

sen.j: その後も秀頼を補佐し、豊臣氏と徳川氏の対立を避けることに尽力した。

sen.j: 戦後に実証的研究が行われるようになると、昭和51年（1976年）に高木昭作は且元が豊臣家の家老でありつつも徳川方の国奉行であることに着目し、関ヶ原の合戦前後の政治状況を考察する際にも注目される。
sen.e: When the demonstration experiment began to be performed after the World War II, Shosaku TAKAGI pointed out in 1976 that Katsumoto was both the servant of TOYOTOMI Family as well as being the kuni (country) bugyo of TOKUGAWA, and he is closely observed to study the political situation before and after the Battle of Sekigahara.

With the growth of empirical research after World War II, Shosaku TAKAGI pointed out in 1976 that Katsumoto was both the chief retainer of the TOYOTOMI and one of TOKUGAWA's national bugyo, and that is important to study the political situation around the time of the Battle of Sekigahara.
